metadata.title: Ultrathin VO2 Nanosheets Self-Assembled into 3D Micro/Nano- Structured Hierarchical Porous Sponge-Like Micro-Bundles for Long-Life and High-Rate Li-Ion Batteries

www.rsc.org/
Ultrathin VO2 Nanosheets Self-Assembled into 3D Micro/NanoStructured Hierarchical Porous Sponge-Like Micro-Bundles for Long-Life and High-Rate Li-Ion Batteries
Pengcheng Liu,a,d* Yuan Xu,a,d Kongjun Zhu,a* Kan Bian,a Jing Wang,a Xu Sun,a Yanfeng Gao,b Hongjie Luo,b Li Lu,c Jinsong Liu a,d
Nanomaterials, especially graphene-like 2D ultrathin ones that possess a wealth of unprecedented functionalities, can
increase the discharge capacity of Li-ion batteries (LIBs), but they still suffer from poor cycling and rate performances due
to their serious self-aggregation and pulverization. Constructing the micro/nano-structures is a quite promising method to
address the above issues. However, it remains a huge challenge to build the 3D hierarchical porous micro/nano-structures
self-assembled from ultrathin nanostructured building blocks, which has prompted extensively great interests. Herein, we
report a facile “hydrolysis-controllable crystallization” strategy to controllably synthesize different dimensional (i.e. 1D, 2D,
and 3D) VO2 (B) nanostructures by a simple one-step high-temperature mixing method under hydrothermal conditions. Especially, a unique 3D micro/nano-structured hierarchical porous sponge-like micro-bundles (SLMBs) self-assembled from
2D crumpled ultrathin VO2 (B)@C nanosheets with a thickness of only ~3.1 nm (denoted as VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs) is synthesized, which is the first report on the synthesis of 2D ultrathin VO2 (B) nanomaterials. Importantly, the intrinsic VO2 (B) crystallization behavior and controllable synthesis mechanism of VO2 (B) micro/nano-structures are revealed for the first time by the density functional theory calculation. The as-synthesized VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs possess the distinct structural advantages, i.e., the large surface area, abundant meso/micropores, robust structure and conductive carbon frameworks,
which make them exhibit the excellent electrochemical performance in terms of long life, high rate, and large capacity as
the cathode materials of LIBs. The discharge capacity is still up to 206 mAh/g after 160 cycles at 100 mA/g, corresponding
to 105% of the initial capacity. Even at a large 1000 mA/g, it still exhibits a high retention of 104% after long-term 1000
cycles. These results indicate that the as-synthesized VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs have great potential for the long-life and high-rate cathode materials of next-generation LIBs.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
The rapid development of electrical vehicles and hybrid electrical vehicles put forward higher demands of long life and high rate for rechargeable lithium-ion batteries (LIBs), which has prompted numerous research interests and efforts.1, 2 Among various promising cathode candidates for the nextgeneration LIBs, vanadium oxides have attracted more and more research interests due to their distinct advantages of high specific capacity, low cost and abundant sources.3-5 In particular, VO2 (B) stands out for both organic and aqueous
LIBs because of its unique V4O10-type bilayers with abundant tunnels (Figure S1) that guarantee the rapid Li+ intercalation/deintercalation.3, 6-8
Nanomaterials have shown huge advantages for various energy storage applications because of the ultra-large specific surface area and ultra-short diffusion path of ions/electrons.911 Various low-dimensional nanostructures (such as 0D nanoparticles, 1D nanowires, 2D nanosheets, etc.),12, 13 especially graphene-like 2D ultrathin nanomaterials which result in a wealth of unprecedented functionalities,14, 15 have exhibited a large superiority for LIBs. Except 2D ultrathin ones, various low-dimensional VO2 (B) nanomaterials, such as nanorods,16 nanobelts17 and nanosheets,18 have been synthesized, and exhibited the higher discharge capacity than the bulk counterpart. However, recent reports reveal that nanostructured electrode materials have still some problems to be urgently addressed. One main problem is that although exhibiting higher capacity, these simplex low-dimensional nanomaterials still suffer from the serious self-aggregation and pulverization during cycling caused by their quite large surface area and energy, which makes nanomaterials lose their advantages, and consequently leads to poor cycling and rate

sections.heading: ARTICLE Journal Name
sections.text:
2 | J. Name., 2012, 00, 1-3 This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx
Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
performance.4, 19, 20 So, it is a huge challenge how to simultaneously develop the advantages of nanomaterials and overcome their disadvantages for the applications of LIBs.
Building 3D micro/nano-structures, especially hierarchical porous ones, consisting of low-dimensional nanoscale building blocks, is a quite promising method to address the above issues.5, 21-27 3D micro/nano-structures can inherit the superior characteristics of nano-building blocks, and synergistically gain additional benefits from the unique microscale secondary architectures, which can make electrode materials possess simultaneously high surface area and decent structural stability.4, 28-35 These fascinating features can effectively avoid the self-aggregation of active nanomaterials, and benefit the insertion/extraction of Li+, so that excellent cycling and rate performances can be obtained. For example, a 3D plumpudding-like Si/C micro/nano-composite was designed and synthesized via quasi-industrial-scale production, and it possessed excellent structural stability, which leads to the ultra-high initial Coulombic efficiency, high volumetric capacity and improved rate and cycling performance.32 3D porous LiFePO4/N-doped rGO composites were synthesized, and showed an ultra-high rate performance for LIBs cathode.23 Hierarchical MoS2 microboxes constructed by ultrathin nanosheets are synthesized by a template-assisted strategy, and manifest high specific capacity and excellent cycling performance.36 However, unfortunately, there are rare reports on 3D micro/nano-structured VO2 (B). Especially, it remains a huge challenge to synthesize 2D ultrathin VO2 (B) nanomaterials, and construct them into 3D hierarchical porous micro/nano-structures by a simple self-assembly method.
Herein, we report a facile “hydrolysis-controllable crystallization” strategy to controllably synthesize different dimensional (i.e. 1D, 2D, and 3D) VO2 (B) nanostructures by a simple one-step high-temperature mixing method (HTMM) under hydrothermal conditions, as shown in Figure 1. Especially, a unique 3D micro/nano-structured VO2 (B) is obtained, i.e. hierarchical porous sponge-like micro-bundles (SLMBs) self-assembled from 2D crumpled ultrathin carboncoated nanosheets with a thickness of only ~3.1 nm (denoted as VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs), which is the first report on the synthesis of 2D ultrathin VO2 (B) nanomaterials. Importantly, the intrinsic nucleation and crystallization behavior of VO2 (B) is revealed for the first time by the density functional theory (DFT) calculation, and consequently the controllable synthesis mechanism of VO2 (B) micro/nano-structures is proposed. The as-synthesized VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs possess the distinct structural advantages (i.e., the large surface area, abundant meso/micropores, robust structure and conductive carbon frameworks with a faster electrochemical kinetics), which make them exhibit the excellent electrochemical performance in terms of long life, high rate, and large capacity as the cathode materials of LIBs.

sections.heading: Experimental
sections.text:
Raw materials
Figure 1. (A) Schematic diagram of “hydrolysis-controllable crystallization” strategy based on HTMM: (AI) hydrolysis process during temperature rising with a photograph inset showing hydrolyzed transparent yellow V2O5 solution, (AII) controllable crystallization process during temperature preservation with a photograph inset showing as-synthesized black precipitates; (B) XRD patterns of the products when the molar ratio of glucose: V2O5 is (I) 0.2, (II) 0.4 and (III) 1.
The starting materials, including V2O5 and glucose (H12C6O6), were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., China. All chemical reagents are analytical grade and used without further purification.
Synthesis of 3D hierarchical porous VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs by HTMM
VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs were synthesized by HTMM (Figure 1A). HTMM is a modified hydrothermal method.32, 33 The starting solutions or raw materials for HTMM are separately heated in a double-chambered autoclave during the temperature rise. When the temperature is increased to the desired reaction temperature, i.e. in temperature preservation period, the raw materials are just mixed to start the hydrothermal reaction. This method avoids effectively the formation of intermediate phases and defects during the temperature rise in the conventional hydrothermal method, which can greatly improve the crystallinity of products. Furthermore, the reaction time can be dramatically shortened because the reaction, nucleation and growth rates are faster, and the transformation from intermediate phases and defects to final products is avoided when the reaction is started at high and desired temperature. HTMM is also a simple method without

sections.text:

Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
long time and complex mixing or stirring process at ambient temperature.
In the present synthesis, V2O5 was used as the vanadium source, and glucose played simultaneously three important roles of the reducing reagent, carbon resource and surfactant. The synthesis process was fast, simple and effective. Firstly, 0.182g V2O5 and 5 ml de-ionized water were placed in one of the two chambers of a Teflon-lined multi-chamber autoclave, and corresponding 5 ml glucose solution (0.2 M) were poured into the another chamber. Then, these solutions would be just mixed when the temperature increased to 240 °C. This temperature would be kept for 6 h at 240 °C. Finally, the assynthesized products were washed several times with deionized water and ethanol after cooling to room temperature, and then dried at 80 °C for 10 h in vacuum.
Synthesis of low-dimensional VO2 (B) nanomaterials by HTMM
When the concentration of glucose solution was adjusted as 0.08 and 0.04 M with keeping other processes unchanged, 2D random distributed VO2 (B) nanosheets and 1D random distributed VO2 (B) nanoribbons were synthesized, respectively.
Synthesis of VO2 (B) nanomaterials by conventional hydrothermal
The synthesis process is as follows: first, V2O5 (5 mmol) was added into 50 ml aqueous solution of glucose (0.02 M); then, the above mixing solution was transferred into the conventional autoclave, and heated at 180 °C for 12 h; finally, the as-formed precipitates were washed several times with deionized water and ethanol, and dried at 80 °C for 10 h in vacuum.

sections.heading: DFT Theoretical calculation
sections.text:
The calculations were performed by using the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) in the framework of density functional theory. The Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional within the generalized-gradient approximation (GGA) was chosen to treat the exchange-correlation interaction of electrons. A kinetic energy cutoff of 400 eV for the planewave basis and a convergence criterion of 10-5 eV for the total energies in the projector augmented wave method were adopted for all DFT calculations. The geometry was fully relaxed until the force on each atom was less than 0.01 eV/Å. The Brillouin zone integration was sampled by a 11×11×1 kgrid mesh.
During the calculations, the VO2 (B) surface was modeled by a five-layer slab model that cleaved from bulk VO2 (B), and 2D periodic boundary condition was employed in the x-y plane. To avoid interactions between adjacent periodic images, a vacuum space of more than 10 A˚ was included in the z direction for the slab model. Furthermore, the surface energy of different plane of VO2 (B) was calculated via the equation of Esur = [EVO2-slab –EVO2-bulk] /A, where E VO2-slab and EVO2-bulk represent the energies of VO2 (B) in the slab and bulk models, respectively. A represents the area of VO2 (B) within the slab model.
Characterization
The phase structure of the resultant powders were determined by powder X-ray diffraction (Bruker D8 Advance, Germany) using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.15418 nm). The morphologies of the prepared products were observed by field emission scanning electron microscopy (HITACHI S-4800, Japan) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM; Tecnai G2 F30 STwin TEM, FEI, USA). The thickness of ultrathin VO2 (B) nanosheets is measured by the atomic force microscope (AFM; MICROMERITICS ASAP2020M, USA). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were carried out with an ESCALab220i-XL spectrometer. The specific surface area and pore size distribution were determined from nitrogen sorption isotherms collected at 77 K using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) desorption analyses, respectively (Quantachrome NOVA 4200e). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA, PERKIN－ELMER Pyris 1, USA) was carried out under air flow with a temperature ramp of 10 °C/min.

sections.heading: Electrochemical testing
sections.text: The active materials of as-synthesized VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs, acetylene black, and PVDF were mixed well into weight ratios of 7:2:1 to obtain a slurry. The obtained slurry was casted on aluminum foil to obtain a laminate. The laminate was dried for 5 min under an incandescent lamp before drying in a vacuum oven at 120 °C for 12 h. The dried laminate was punched into round discs with diameters of 12 mm. The surface density of active materials is ~2.2 mg/cm2. Coin cells (2032) were assembled in an argon-filled glove box with H2O and O2 concentrations of less than 1 ppm. A lithium metal foil was used as a counter electrode, and Celgard2400 was used as a separator. The electrolyte solution was 1.0 M LiPF6 in EC/DEC (1:1 vol/vol). Galvanostatic charge/discharge measurement was performed by a multichannel battery testing system (LAND CT2001A). Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) and cyclic voltammetry (CV) were measured by electrochemical workstation (Princeton PARSTAT MC).

sections.heading: Results and discussion
sections.text:
The present “hydrolysis-controllable crystallization” strategy based on HTMM includes three processes of hydrolysis, nucleation, and controllable crystal growth. Figure 1A shows the intuitive schematic diagram of the HTMM synthesis. The HTMM is a modified hydrothermal method. The raw materials (i.e. V2O5 powder and glucose) are separately heated in a double-chambered autoclave during the temperature rising (Figure 1AI). In this period, the hydrolysis process of V2O5 occurs, and finally a transparent yellow solution (the photograph inset of Figure 1AI), including abundant hydrolyzed V-ions, forms. When the temperature is increased to the desired reaction temperature (i.e. in temperature preservation period), the raw materials are just mixed to start the hydrothermal reaction (Figure 1AII). In this period, the nucleation and controllable crystal growth process occurs, so that the black precipitates form (the photograph inset of Figure 1AII). Different amount of glucose can play different roles during controllable crystal growth. The unique advantage

Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
of the “hydrolysis-controllable crystallization” strategy is that the dimension of VO2 (B) nanomaterials can be easily controlled by the re-nucleation and controllable crystal growth of hydrolyzed V-ions through the simple HTMM, and a unique 3D hierarchical porous VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs is synthesized, as shown in Figures 2 and 3.

sections.heading: Synthesis of low-dimensional VO2 (B) nanomaterials
sections.text:
We can controllably and easily synthesize low-dimensional VO2 (B) nanostructures of 1D nanoribbons and 2D nanosheets by simply adjusting the molar ratio of glucose: V2O5 as 0.2 and 0.4 respectively (Figure 2). When the molar ratio of glucose: V2O5 is 0.2, the random distributed 1D nanoribbons are obtained with the length of ~3 μm and width of ~100 nm (Figure 2a). With the molar ratio increased to 0.4, the morphology become random distributed 2D nanosheets with the smaller length of ~1 μm and larger width of ~500 nm (Figure 2d). Their morphology features can further be seen in Figures 2b and e. The XRD patterns (Figure 1B) confirm that all products are pure monoclinic VO2 (B) with C2/m space group (standard PDF card: 81-2392, the lattice parameters of a = 12.09 Å, b = 3.70 Å, c = 6.43Å, β = 107.0°). However, the XRD pattern of products (i.e. 1D VO2 (B) nanoribbons) synthesized when the molar ratio is 0.2 exhibits an obvious preferred orientation (Figure 1BI), which usually reveals that the as-obtained products exhibit a 1D morphology along a preferred and faster growth orientation.39, 40 Then, the previous preferred orientation disappears when the molar ratio increases to 0.4 (Figure 1BII), accompanying with that the products are transformed to 2D VO2 (B) nanosheets. The results of XRD analysis agree well with those of SEM observations. The HRTEM image (Figure 2c) shows the clear lattice fringes of 1D VO2 (B) nanoribbons with the spacing of 0.61 and 0.37 nm, corresponding to the (001) and (201) lattice plane. Moreover, 2D VO2 (B) nanosheets have the same lattice fringes (Figure 2f). Combined with the crystal structure of VO2 (B) along b axis shown in Figure S1a, it can be confirmed that the nanoribbons and nanosheets have the same geometrical orientation and exposed facets with the length direction along [100], width direction along [001] and upper surface of (010). The corresponding schematic diagram is intuitively illustrated in Figure 4a. Furthermore, it can also be found that the crystallinity of VO2 (B) nanoribbons is much
better than that of VO2 (B) synthesized by conventional hydrothermal with the same molar ratio of glucose: V2O5 (Figure S2), which reveals that HTMM can greatly improve the crystallinity of products.

sections.heading: Synthesis of 3D hierarchical porous VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs
sections.text:
Excitingly, we can also controllably synthesize the 3D hierarchical porous VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs by adjusting the molar ratio of glucose: V2O5 as 1 (Figure 3). The XRD pattern (Figure 1BIII) confirms that the as-synthesized products are pure monoclinic VO2 (B). Figure 3a shows the morphology of SLMBs. From the inset of Figure 3a, it can clearly be seen that the SLMBs consist of 2D crumpled ultrathin nanosheets through stacking, and there are abundant pores like sponges. The morphology features of SLMBs can further be observed in Figure S3a. Figure S4 shows the morphology evolution of SLMBs for different reaction time, which reveals the selfassembly growth process of SLMBs through the stacking of ultrathin nanosheets based on the oriented attachment mechanism.37, 38, 41
To precisely measure the thickness of these ultrathin VO2 (B) nanosheets (building blocks), we delaminate SLMBs into the free-standing single-layer nanosheets by immersing SLMBs into DMSO and sonication, which is based on the fabrication method of single-layer Ti3C2 (MXene) nanosheets. 42-44 Then, the supernatant is retained after centrifuging. The colloidal state of the supernatant is found by the observation of the Tyndall scattering effect when passing a red laser beam through the solution (Figure 3b), which reveals the presence of free-standing single-layer nanosheets in supernatant.42 The morphology of free-standing single-layer nanosheets is more intuitively observed by AFM image (Figure 3c). These nanosheets are quite thin with a thickness of ~3.1 nm (Figure 3d), which is the first report on the synthesis of 2D ultrathin VO2 (B) nanomaterials.
From the HRTEM image (Figure S3b), it can be seen that VO2 (B) nanosheet is coated by a continuous carbon shell. Moreover, the uniform carbon coating can further be confined by EDX element mappings (Figure 3e). The survey and V 2p spectrum for VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs is presented in Figure S5 through XPS measurements. In the peak fitting of core level C 1s spectra (Figure 3f), the peaks at 284.5 eV, 285.8 eV, and 287.7 eV correspond to C-C, C-O, and C=O bonds, which further proves the existence of carbon in final products.45-48 Furthermore, the C-V peak at 283.1 eV reveals that there is a strong binding between VO2 (B) nanosheets and carbon shells,49-52 which can increase the intensity and stability of the whole structure. The carbon content is ~11% through the analysis of TG (Figure S6).
The porous characteristics were investigated by N2 adsorption/desorption measurements (Figure 3g). The BET specific surface area of VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs is up to 98.7 m 2/g, which is about 5 times higher than that of low-dimensional nanoribbons (~20.8 m2/g) shown in Figure S7. The specific surface area of VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs is also much larger than those of other VO2 (B) micro/nano-structures, such as hollow microspheres (22.3 m2/g),19 nanoscroll buffered hybrid

Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
Figure 3. Comprehensive characterizations of 3D hierarchical porous VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs when the molar ratio of glucose: V2O5 is 1. (a) SEM image; (b) photograph showing Tyndall scattering effect of delaminated free-standing single-layer ultrathin VO2 (B) nanosheets in the solution; (c) AFM image of the as-obtained nanosheets; (d) corresponding height profile of the as-obtained nanosheets; (e) EDX element mapping; (f) XPS spectrum of core level C 1s; (h) nitrogen adsorption−desorption isotherm with the inset of corresponding pore size distribution pattern; (h) structural schematic diagram of 3D hierarchical porous sponge-like micro-bundles.
nanostructures (23.2 m2/g),3 micro/nano-structured mesocrystals (28.4 m2/g),53 GO composites (35 m2/g),54 mesoporous nanowires (46.7 m2/g)55 and 3D GO-nanosheet flowers (71.6 m 2 /g). 18 From the pore-size distribution pattern in the inset, VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs possess abundant both micropores and mesopores.
So, based on the above results, the structural schematic diagram of VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs can reasonably be illustrated in Figure 3h. The building blocks of such micro/nano-structured SLMBs are crumpled ultrathin VO2 (B) nanosheets with uniform carbon shells. VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs consist of these VO2 (B)@C nanosheets through self-assembled stacking. Furthermore, the stacking of VO2 (B)@C nanosheets results in the connection of carbon shells with each other, so that a conductive carbon framework can be built. Simultaneously, abundant meso/micro-pores can also be formed during stacking.
Importantly, the as-synthesized VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs can possess the unique structural advantages: (a) the building blocks (2D ultrathin VO2 (B)@C nanosheets) offer an ultrashort diffusion pathway for Li+/electrons;24 (b) the conductive carbon frameworks can not only provide a faster electrochemical kinetics, but also play a structural buffering role to guarantee the whole 3D microstructures robust enough, and simultaneously lead to the formation of a stable thin SEI layer on the outer surface of electrode materials; 32 (c) the hierarchical porous features have dual important functions: it can provide a larger surface area to increase more active sites for electrochemical reactions; simultaneously, the abundant meso/micro-pores can also buffer the mechanical stress caused by the large volume change during charging/discharging.
DFT theoretical calculation and reaction mechanism
To clearly understand the essential reason of the above morphology control and reaction mechanism in the present “hydrolysis-controllable crystallization” strategy based on HTMM, the surface energy of intrinsic VO2 (B) is theoretically calculated based on DFT, as shown in Figure 4b. It can be seen that (100) crystal face has the highest surface energy of 126 meV, and (010) has the lowest 75 meV. This results in that in order to keep systemic energies the most stable and lowest, products will preferentially and intrinsically grow along the [100] direction to decrease the area of the highest energy (100) crystal face, and keep the exposed large facet as the lowest
Figure 4. Schematic diagram of (a) geometrical orientation of 1D VO2 (B) nanoribbons and 2D VO2 (B) nanosheets; (b) DFT theoretical calculation of surface energies for intrinsicVO2 (B); (c) intrinsic nucleation process of VO2 (B).

Figure 5. Schematic illustrations of the reaction and formation mechanism of different dimensional VO2 (B) nanostructures. (A) 1D small crystal nucleuses; (B) 1D random distributed nanoribbons when the molar ratio of glucose: V2O5 is 0.2; (C) 2D random distributed nanosheets when the ratio is 0.4; (D) 3D hierarchical porous VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs when the ratio is 1.
energy (010), which agrees well with TEM observations. On the other hand, an intrinsic nucleation process of VO2 (B) can also be concluded reasonably (Figure 4c), and actually occurs in the present synthesis. Firstly, V atoms hydrolyze as VO6 octahedrons, which has been in detail discussed in our previous work. 41 These octahedrons will connect with each other along [100] direction to form long chains according to a condensation reaction of the oxolation mechanism.41, 56-58 Then, these chains can connect along [001] direction to form a layer through the olation.41, 56-58 Next, these layers stack together along [010] direction to construct the framework structure of VO2 (B). The growth rate of [100] direction is the fastest due to the highest energy of (100), which finally results in that the formed crystal nucleuses possess intrinsically 1D morphology with length direction along [100].
After the nucleation, the different dimensional VO2 (B) nanostructures can be controllably synthesized during the controllable crystal growth of these small 1D crystal nucleuses (Figure 5A) by adjusting the molar ratio of glucose: V2O5, as shown in Figure 5. When the amount of glucose is less (Figure 5B), nucleuses will intrinsically connect with each other along [100] to become 1D nanoribbons for decreasing the area of the highest energy (100) based on the self-assembly oriented attachment mechanism.37, 38, 41 Here, glucose just plays a role of reducing reagent. When the molar ratio increases to 0.4
(Figure 5C), glucose can play dual important roles of reducing reagent and surfactant. Some surplus glucose can adhere to the highest energy (100) to limit its preferred growth, which is equivalently good for the growth along [001] width direction.59-61 So, 2D nanosheets with the larger width and smaller length can be obtained. When the molar ratio further increases to 1 (Figure 5D), more glucose can not only adhere to the high energy facets, but also adhere to the low energy upper and lower surfaces of (010) to induce the crumpled ultrathin nanosheets to stack with each other through selfassembly.62-64 Finally, 3D VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs are obtained. Here, glucose can also play another important role of carbon source.

sections.heading: Electrochemical performance for LIBs
sections.text:
Subsequently, 3D hierarchical porous VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs and low-dimensional VO2 (B) nanoribbons were assembled as the cathode materials of LIBs to evaluate their electrochemical performance (Figure 6). At the current density of 100 mA/g, the second discharge specific capacities of VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs and VO2 (B) nanoribbons are 196 and 166 mAh/g respectively (Figure 6a). The capacity of VO2 (B) nanoribbons decreases to 142 mAh/g after 120 cycles, corresponding to 85% of the second capacity. However, for VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs, the capacity can maintain more stable during cycling, and 206 mAh/g can be delivered even after longer 160 cycles, corresponding to 105% of the second capacity, which reveals that VO2 (B)@C-

sections.heading: Journal Name ARTICLE
sections.text:
This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx J. Name., 2013, 00, 1-3 | 7
Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
Figure 6. Electrochemical measurements of 3D hierarchical porous VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs and low-dimensional VO2 (B) nanoribbons. (a) Comparison of cycling performance at the current density of 100 mA/g; (b) comparison of rate performance; (c) long-term cycling performance of SLMBs at a large current density of 1000 mA/g with the inset of the electrode SEM image after 1000 cycles; (d) comparison of electrochemical impedance spectroscopy pattern; (e) photograph of 10 green LEDs powered by one coin cell applied SLMBs as positive electrode materials after being cycled 1000 times at a large current density of 1000 mA/g.
SLMBs can greatly improve the cycling performance. The Coulombic Efficiency of VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs during the whole cycling is close to 100%. It can also be found that the capacity of VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs increases gradually after initial several cycles, which may be related to the activation process that is caused by the gradual wetting by the electrolyte soaking, especially for the 3D porous nanostructures.21, 65 Figure S8 shows the CV curves of VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs and VO2 (B) nanoribbons. It can be seen that the CV curves of VO2 (B)@CSLMBs are better overlapped, which also indicates that VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs possess the higher reversibility and better capacity retention.66 The excellent cycling performance of VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs is related to their unique structural advantages, i.e., ultrathin building blocks, abundant meso/micropores, robust structure and conductive carbon frameworks. So, the volume change of VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs caused by lithiation/delithiation during cycling is very small, and the mechanical stress can be buffered well, which can provide a superior cycling performance, as shown in Figure 7. But, for nanoribbons, the volume change is very huge, and the stress could not be completely and promptly released. Furthermore, these low dimensional nanoribbons tend to aggregate together during cycling,4 which also results in the poor electrochemical performance of nanoribbons. It should be also noted that the capacity retention of 105% for VO2 (B)@CSLMBs after 160 cycles is much better than those of other VO2 (B) nanomaterials or micro/nano-structures, such as 3D GOnanosheet flowers (60% after 50 cycles),18 nanobelts@C (80%
after 50 cycles),67 micro/nano-structured mesocrystals (74% after 50 cycles),53 nanoscoll buffered hybrid nanostructures (85% after 100 cycles),3 and hollow microspheres (90% after 100 cycles).19 The detailed comparison of electrochemical performances between the VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs and other electrode materials is listed in Table S1. Furthermore, Figure S9a shows that the discharge curves of VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs are better overlapped compared with those of VO2 (B) nanoribbons, which also indicates the higher reversibility and better capacity retention of VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs. Moreover, the overpotential of VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs is much smaller than that of VO2 (B) nanoribbons (Figure S9b), showing higher electronic and ionic conductivity.3, 19
To further evaluate the advantage of VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs, the rate capability at the progressively increased current density ranging from 50 to 3000 mA/g was measured (Figure 6b). For VO2 (B) nanoribbons, the discharge capacities of 174, 145, 126, 114, 95, 70 and 54 mAh/g can be obtained at 50, 100, 300, 500, 1000, 2000 and 3000 mA/g, respectively. However, for VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs, the higher capacity of 243, 210, 188, 173, 147, 119 and 100 mAh/g can be delivered at same current densities. It is exciting for VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs that when the current density is turned back to 500 mA/g, a higher capacity of 180 mAh/g can be delivered, and 100% of capacity can be maintained in the following 100 cycles, which is also better than those of other VO2 (B) nanomaterials or micro/nanostructures.3, 18, 19, 53, 67 Such results suggest that VO2 (B)@CSLMBs possess the excellent rate performance. To further explore the outstanding cycling performance of VO2 (B)@CSLMBs, its long-life cycles were measured at a large current density of 1000 mA/g (Figure 6c). The whole cycling is stable. The high discharge capacity of 142 mAh/g can also be delivered even after long-term 1000 cycles, corresponding to 104% of the second capacity, which is much higher than 94 mAh/g of VO2 (B) nanoribbons (Figure S9c). The morphology of the electrode for VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs after 1000 cycles was checked (inset of Figure 6c). It shows that the architecture of SLMBs is well preserved without the obvious deformation or damage. This reveals that the present SLMBs structure are obviously robust enough to guarantee the highly reversible intercalation/deintercalation of Li+, leading to both superior cycling and rate performance.
Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements were carried out to further evaluate the electrochemical kinetics (Figure 6d). Generally, the impedance spectra consist of a semicircle in the high frequency range that is assigned to the charge-transfer resistance at the electrodeelectrolyte interface, and a straight line in the low frequency range that implies the Li-ion diffusion-controlled process in the solid electrode.32 In the Nyquist plots, the charge-transfer resistance (~45 Ω) of VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs is quite smaller than that (~189 Ω) of VO2 (B) nanoribbons, which is caused by that 3D hierarchical porous VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs possess the more electrochemical active sites and better conductivity. This suggests that VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs have a higher electronic conductivity and faster electrochemical kinetics, which is benefit to the superior rate and cycling performance.4, 46

sections.heading: ARTICLE Journal Name
sections.text:
8 | J. Name., 2012, 00, 1-3 This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx
Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
Furthermore, the low-frequency slope angles for VO2 (B)@CSLMBs and VO2 (B) nanoribbons are nearly same, indicating good Li-ions diffusivity in both electrodes due to the same lowfrequency tail,31 which is related to that both of lowdimensional nano-building blocks (i.e., nanoribbons) in VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs and VO2 (B) nanoribbons can facilitate the Li-ion diffusion in electrode materials. Figure S10 further shows the EIS results of VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs and VO2 (B) nanoribbons after long-term cycling. It can be seen clearly that the chargetransfer resistance of VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs increased slightly to 91 Ω, while that of VO2 (B) nanoribbons jumped to 479 Ω, which also reveals that VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs exhibit the better stability.66 Excitingly, 10 green light emitting diodes (LEDs) in parallel can easily be powered by the coin cell cycled after 1000 times at high 1000 mA/g (Figure 6e).
The excellent electrochemical performance of the 3D hierarchical porous VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs can be related to the unique structural advantages in several aspects. (1) The hierarchical porous features of SLMBs provide a larger surface, so that more active sites are increased for electrochemical reactions, which can greatly improve the capacity. (2) The excellent rate properties are due to the 2D ultrathin nanosheet building blocks with an ultra-short diffusion pathway for Li+/electrons and the conductive carbon frameworks with faster electrochemical kinetics. (3) Compared with lowdimensional nanomaterials, the abundant meso/micropores and conductive carbon frameworks in SLMBs can play a structural buffering role to guarantee the whole micro/nanostructures robust and buffer the mechanical stress caused by the large volume change during lithiation/delithiation (Figure 7), which can provide a superior cycling and rate performance; (4) The present micro/nano-structure can effectively avoid the self-aggregation and pulverization of the low-dimensional nanostructures, so that ultrathin nano-building-blocks can adequately exploit their advantages, which also guarantees the excellent electrochemical performance. These results indicate that the as-synthesized VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs have great potential for the long-life and high-rate cathode materials of next-generation LIBs.

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text:
In summary, we report a facile “hydrolysis-controllable crystallization” strategy to controllably synthesize different
dimensional (i.e. 1D, 2D, and 3D) VO2 (B) nanostructures by a simple one-step HTMM. Especially, the unique 3D micro/nanostructured hierarchical porous VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs with the ultrathin building blocks of only ~3.1 nm thickness are obtained, which is the first report on the synthesis of 2D ultrathin VO2 (B) nanomaterials. The as-synthesized VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs possess the distinct structural advantages (i.e., the large surface area, abundant meso/micropores, robust structure and conductive carbon frameworks with a faster electrochemical kinetics), which make them exhibit the excellent electrochemical performance with long life, high rate, and large capacity as the cathode materials of LIBs. Importantly, the intrinsic VO2 (B) crystallization behavior and controllable synthesis mechanism of VO2 (B) micro/nanostructures is revealed for the first time by the DFT calculation, which can offer a helpful guidance to design and synthesize more fascinating other vanadium oxide-based nanomaterials. Furthermore, constructing the present interesting SLMBs-type micro/nano-structures can become a simple and versatile strategy to prepare other more advanced electrode materials for the energy storage applications.
